The official languages include Assamese, Bengali, Bodo, Dogri, Gujarati, Hindi, Kannada, Kashmiri, Konkani, Maithili, Malayalam, Manipuri, Marathi, Nepali, Odia, Punjabi, Sanskrit, Santali, Sindhi, Tamil, Telugu, Urdu.
description: This table lists the twelve large language models (LLMs) whose tokenizers were evaluated in the study.  For each LLM, it indicates whether the tokenizer was tested on all 22 official Indian languages (as per the Indian Constitution's Eighth Schedule) and specifies the availability of the model (proprietary or open-source). The 22 languages are: Assamese, Bengali, Bodo, Dogri, Gujarati, Hindi, Kannada, Kashmiri, Konkani, Maithili, Malayalam, Manipuri, Marathi, Nepali, Odia, Punjabi, Sanskrit, Santali, Sindhi, Tamil, Telugu, and Urdu.

caption:
Table 2: 
Average NSL Values Across Models for 22 Languages (lower is better).
The bold values indicate the best-performing tokenizer for each language.
description: This table presents a comparative analysis of the performance of tokenizers from twelve different Large Language Models (LLMs) across all 22 official languages of India.  The key metric used for comparison is the Normalized Sequence Length (NSL). A lower NSL value indicates a more efficient tokenizer.  For each language, the table shows the NSL score for each of the 12 LLMs, highlighting in bold the LLM with the best-performing tokenizer for that specific language.  This allows for a direct comparison of tokenizer efficiency across various LLMs and languages.
